Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: With the goal of attracting and retaining freshmen and sophomores in the STEM majors, the departments of Computer Science, Mathematical Sciences, Chemistry, and Physics and Astronomy at Appalachian State University (ASU) established the Appalachian Undergraduate Academy of Science (Academy). This project recognizes the importance of mentoring, mathematics readiness, early involvement in multidisciplinary research, and problem solving skills and involves implementing strategies proven successful at ASU and other institutions. The Academy is coordinating activities for ASU students, faculty, and staff that include: running a summer bridge program to instruct entering students under-prepared in mathematics; establishing science and math clusters that engage undergraduates in research and collaborative learning; establishing a residential learning community; providing special advising, tutoring, and a supervised study hall for Academy scholars; creating a dedicated mentoring program for community college transfer students; defining a common general education curriculum for Academy scholars in order to provide additional peer-support; and including upper-division students by involving them as peer-mentors. ASU plans to institutionalize the effective Academy components.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Appalachian Undergraduate Academy of Science, funded by an NSF STEP grant [0756928, $1M] and terminating in spring 2014, laid a strong mentoring foundation by providing experience for faculty-mentoring, peer-mentoring, collaborative learning, early engagement of students, and summer bridge programs. The Academy allowed freshmen, sophomores, and transfer students to participate in research clusters under the supervision of faculty mentors from Chemistry, Computer Science, Geology, Mathematics, and Physics & Astronomy. A limited number of students from the local high school and the Boone Home School High School Program have also participated.

The distribution of the Academy’s scholars over 11 semesters for 286 scholars of the program is shown in Figure 1. At present, 53 scholars (32% chemistry, 21% CS, 21% Biology, 13% Physics & Astronomy, 7% Mathematics, and 8% Geology) have completed their degrees resulting in a 71% retention rate. The rate of 71% for the STEP is lower than the retention rate of our CSEMS/S-STEM programs (the CSEMS/S-STEM programs provided students with greater financial support) but still much higher than rates reported in the literature and better than the university’s average for the same majors.

Among the 80% of the alumni who submitted a post-graduation survey, 55% were pursuing a graduate degree, 30% had joined the job market, and 15% were in transition to the job market or graduate school. Academy students graduated from ASU with a higher GPA (3.28) than the average STEM graduate (2.88). In addition to maintaining above average GPAs, the Academy students presented at conferences, received scholarships and awards, and participated in internships and REUs.

Our scholars had 78 conference presentaions, received 47 awards and scholarships, and nine of them atteneded external REU programs.
